p: These changes are responsible for the production of a range of atmospheric pollutants, some of which contribute to climate change alongside CO 2 and all of which affect life on the planet. Since pre-industrial times, there has been a sharp and accelerating increase in levels of the major, long-lived GHGs CO 2, CH 4 (methane), and N 2O (nitrous oxide) [ 18, 78, 79]. Gases such as NO and NO 2, produced during fossil fuel combustion, also affect GHG accumulation via atmospheric reactions which produce GHGs or alter their half-lives [ 80].
